An approach to membrane computing under inexactitude

J. Casasnovas    J. Miró    M. Moyà    F. Rosselló
Abstract

In this paper we introduce a fuzzy version of symport/antiport membrane systems. Our fuzzy membrane systems handle possibly inexact copies of reactives and their rules are endowed with threshold functions that determine whether a rule can be applied or not to a given set of objects, depending of the degree of accuracy of these objects to the reactives specified in the rule. We prove that these fuzzy membrane systems generate exactly the recursively enumerable finite-valued fuzzy subsets of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N.

Keywords: Membrane computing; P-systems; Fuzzy sets; Universality; Biochemistry.

1 Introduction

Membrane computing is a formal computational paradigm, invented in 1998 by Gh. Păun [Paun1], that rewrites multisets of objects within a spatial structure inspired by the membrane structure of living cells and according to evolution rules that are reminiscent of the processes that take place inside cells. Most approaches to membrane computing developed so far have been exact: the objects used in the computations are exact copies of the reactives involved in the biochemical reactions modelled by the rules, and every application of a given rule always yields exact copies of the objects it is assumed to produce. But, in everyday’s practice, one finds that cells do not behave in this way. Biochemical reactions may deal with inexact, mutated copies of the reactives involved in them, and errors may happen when a biochemical reaction takes place. These errors can be due, for instance, to the inexactitude of the chemical compounds used or to unnoticed changes in the surrounding conditions.

The inexactitude underlying cell processes made Gh. Păun ask in his very first list of open problems in membrane computing [probl1], dated October 2000, for the development of “approximate” mathematical approaches. A first answer to this question was given by A. Obtułowicz and Gh. Păun himself by extending the classical model to a probabilistic one [ObP]. Actually, these authors discussed several ways of introducing probabilities in membrane computing: at the level of objects (each object lies in a membrane with a certain probability), at the level of rules (at each moment, each rule is fired with a certain probability), and at the level of targets (outputs of applications of rules are moved to each possible membrane with a certain probability).

Beyond this probabilistic approach, Gh. Păun has asked more specifically for the development of a rough set version of membrane computing in a later list of open problems [Pa-probl] and Obtułowicz [Obr] has discussed several possible rough set based mathematical models of uncertainty that could be used in membrane computing. In the Concluding Remarks section of their aforementioned paper [ObP], A. Obtułowicz and Gh. Păun proposed the use of fuzzy set approaches to introduce uncertainty effects in membrane computing. But, although the probabilistic approaches developed in that paper can be easily generalized to the possibilistic setting, other fuzzy approaches to the membership of objects to membranes may have some drawbacks. For instance, the classical rules of fuzzy logic —for the usual operations between fuzzy sets valued in [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ] and involutive complement operation c𝑐citalic_c [Klir]— entail that, for every membrane (including the environment) m0subscript𝑚0m_{0}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the maximum of the membership values of a given object to all membranes other than m0subscript𝑚0m_{0}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must be the image under c𝑐citalic_c of its membership value to m0subscript𝑚0m_{0}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, it is straightforward to prove that this rule implies that, for every object, there exists some α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1]italic_α ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] such that its membership value to each membrane is α∧c⁢(α)𝛼𝑐𝛼\alpha\wedge c(\alpha)italic_α ∧ italic_c ( italic_α ) for all membranes but one, and α∨c⁢(α)𝛼𝑐𝛼\alpha\vee c(\alpha)italic_α ∨ italic_c ( italic_α ) for the remaining membrane: almost a crisp situation.

Nevertheless, there is one uncertainty aspect that cannot be handled by means of probabilistic methods and that is suitable to being attacked using a fuzzy set approach: the inexactitude of the reactives involved in computations. I.e., the fact that the actual objects used in computations, as well as the actual output of the latter, need not be exact copies of the reactives that are assumed to be used in the computations or to be produced by them but only approximate copies of these reactives. In this paper we present a first approach to the use of fuzzy methods to handle this kind of uncertainty. For simplicity, we consider only symport/antiport systems [Paun2] —membrane systems whose rules only move reactives through membranes— but it is straightforward to extend our approach to other models of membrane computing. Our fuzzy symport/antiport systems also move objects through membranes, but now these objects can be inexact copies of reactives and each rule is endowed with threshold functions that determine whether it can be applied or not to a given set of objects, depending of the degree of approximation of these objects to the reactives specified in the rule. Then we prove that these fuzzy membrane systems are universal in the sense that they generate exactly the recursively enumerable finite-valued fuzzy subsets of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N.

2 Preliminaries

In this section we recall some concepts on fuzzy sets and multisets and on symport/antiport membrane systems, and we take the opportunity to establish some notations and conventions, some of them not the standard ones, that we shall use.

To simplify the notations, from now on we shall denote this set ℕ∪{∞}ℕ\mathbb{N}\cup\{\infty\}blackboard_N ∪ { ∞ } by ℕ∞subscriptℕ\mathbb{N}_{\infty}blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

2.2 Crisp symport/antiport membrane systems

In this subsection we explain in detail the basic model of membrane systems with symport/antiport rules, with notations that are not the usual ones but that will be helpful in the generalization of this model to the fuzzy setting. The interested reader can look up Chapter 4 of Gh. Păun’s textbook on molecular computing [Paun3] and the references cited therein for more information on this model of computation.

Given an alphabet V𝑉Vitalic_V, we denote by V*superscript𝑉V^{*}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the set of words over V𝑉Vitalic_V. Given a word w∈V*𝑤superscript𝑉w\in V^{*}italic_w ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we denote by |w|𝑤|w|| italic_w | the length of w𝑤witalic_w and, given a letter a∈V𝑎𝑉a\in Vitalic_a ∈ italic_V, by |w|asubscript𝑤𝑎|w|_{a}| italic_w | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the number of occurrences of a𝑎aitalic_a in w𝑤witalic_w.

A membrane structure μ𝜇\muitalic_μ is a finite rooted tree whose nodes are called membranes. We shall always denote by M𝑀Mitalic_M the set of membranes of a membrane structure and, in practice, we shall assume that these membranes are injectively labelled by natural numbers, in such a way that the root’s label is 1111. The edges of μ𝜇\muitalic_μ are oriented pointing to the root.

This tree represents a hierarchical structure of nested membranes, with the edges representing the relation “being directly inside”: an edge going from a membrane m𝑚mitalic_m to a membrane m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT means that m𝑚mitalic_m is directly included in m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The tree’s root 1111 is then called the skin membrane, because it surrounds the whole membrane system, and the tree’s leaves are called elementary membranes, because no further membrane lies inside them.

We expand every membrane structure μ𝜇\muitalic_μ by adding a new node to it labelled e⁢n⁢v𝑒𝑛𝑣envitalic_e italic_n italic_v and an arc going from 1 to e⁢n⁢v𝑒𝑛𝑣envitalic_e italic_n italic_v; let μ¯¯𝜇\overline{\mu}over¯ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG denote the resulting tree and M¯¯𝑀\overline{M}over¯ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG its set of nodes M∪{e⁢n⁢v}𝑀𝑒𝑛𝑣M\cup\{env\}italic_M ∪ { italic_e italic_n italic_v }. This new node e⁢n⁢v𝑒𝑛𝑣envitalic_e italic_n italic_v is called the environment, because it surrounds the skin membrane. In this way, e⁢n⁢v𝑒𝑛𝑣envitalic_e italic_n italic_v becomes the root of μ¯¯𝜇\overline{\mu}over¯ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG. Although, formally, e⁢n⁢v𝑒𝑛𝑣envitalic_e italic_n italic_v is not a membrane, when we generically talk about membranes, we shall include it unless we explicitly state otherwise.

For every m∈M𝑚𝑀m\in Mitalic_m ∈ italic_M, we shall denote by ε⁢(m)𝜀𝑚\varepsilon(m)italic_ε ( italic_m ) the target node of the arc in μ¯¯𝜇\overline{\mu}over¯ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG whose source node is m𝑚mitalic_m, i.e., the membrane which m𝑚mitalic_m is directly included into. Notice that ε⁢(1)=e⁢n⁢v𝜀1𝑒𝑛𝑣\varepsilon(1)=envitalic_ε ( 1 ) = italic_e italic_n italic_v, and that if m≠1𝑚1m\neq 1italic_m ≠ 1, then ε⁢(m)∈M𝜀𝑚𝑀\varepsilon(m)\in Mitalic_ε ( italic_m ) ∈ italic_M.

We understand that every m∈M¯𝑚¯𝑀m\in\overline{M}italic_m ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG defines a region Kmsubscript𝐾𝑚K_{m}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For an elementary membrane, it would represent the space enclosed by it, and for any other membrane it would represent the space comprised between this membrane and those directly included in it. The e⁢n⁢v𝑒𝑛𝑣envitalic_e italic_n italic_v node also defines a region Ke⁢n⁢vsubscript𝐾𝑒𝑛𝑣K_{env}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_n italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which would represent the space outside the skin membrane: the environment, indeed. A finite sequence of transitions between configurations of a P-system ΠΠ\Piroman_Π, starting with the initial configuration, is called a computation with respect to ΠΠ\Piroman_Π. A computation C𝐶Citalic_C halts when it reaches a halting configuration (H⁢(C)m)m∈M¯subscript𝐻subscript𝐶𝑚𝑚¯𝑀(H(C)_{m})_{m\in\overline{M}}( italic_H ( italic_C ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where no rule can be applied. A computation that does not halt does not yield any output.

We have now the following result; see [Paun2, Paun3, MPP].

Theorem 2.1

A subset of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N is recursively enumerable if and only if it is generated by some P-system.

Moreover, every recursively enumerable subset of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N can be generated by a P-system that satisfies the following conditions:

  • •

    its membrane structure has only two nodes, and the output membrane is the elementary one;

  • •

    it has only symport rules;

  • •

    all reactives used by the P-system are output reactives;

  • •

    the rules associated to the output membrane are (α,i⁢n)𝛼𝑖𝑛(\alpha,in)( italic_α , italic_i italic_n ), (#,i⁢n)#𝑖𝑛(\#,in)( # , italic_i italic_n ) and (#,o⁢u⁢t)#𝑜𝑢𝑡(\#,out)( # , italic_o italic_u italic_t ) for some specific reactives α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and ##\##, and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is the only reactive that may enter the output membrane in any halting computation;

  • •

    in the initial configuration, both the skin membrane and the output membrane do not contain any copy of this reactive α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. □□\Box□

Remark 1

Notice that last theorem establishes that every recursively enumerable subset of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N is generated by a P-system all whose reactives are considered as output reactives. Since, by Church-Turing Thesis, a P-system with a set of output reactives specified will generate a recursively enumerable subset of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N, we deduce that the specification of a set of output reactives does not increase the computational power of the model, as we claimed when we defined our P-systems. Besides, we also have that every recursively enumerable subset of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N is generated by a P-system with only one output reactive: the only reactive α𝛼\alphaitalic_α that may enter the output membrane in any halting computation in the P-system given by the last theorem.

3 The fuzzy model

We assume henceforth the existence of a universe X𝑋Xitalic_X containing all objects we use in computations.

Roughly described, a fuzzy P-system will be a structure similar to a crisp P-system, supported on a membrane structure that defines regions whose contents evolve following rules that specify the transport of reactives through membranes. But the details will be quite different.

To begin with, we shall use reactives as “ideal definitions” of chemical compounds, and hence they are fuzzy subsets of X𝑋Xitalic_X: for every reactive v:X→[0,1]:𝑣→𝑋01v:X\to[0,1]italic_v : italic_X → [ 0 , 1 ], we understand that v⁢(x)=t𝑣𝑥𝑡v(x)=titalic_v ( italic_x ) = italic_t denotes that the object x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in Xitalic_x ∈ italic_X is a copy of v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in Vitalic_v ∈ italic_V with a degree t𝑡titalic_t of exactitude. So, v⁢(x)=1𝑣𝑥1v(x)=1italic_v ( italic_x ) = 1 means that x𝑥xitalic_x is an exact copy of the reactive v𝑣vitalic_v, and v⁢(x)=0𝑣𝑥0v(x)=0italic_v ( italic_x ) = 0 means that x𝑥xitalic_x cannot represent in any way the reactive v𝑣vitalic_v.

Actually, every reactive will be, for the purposes of each fuzzy P-system, a finite-valued fuzzy subset of X𝑋Xitalic_X: this represents that, in any fuzzy P-system, only a finite set of values of accuracy of objects to reactives will be taken into account. This can be seen as translating nature’s discreteness, or that the accuracy of an object to a reactive cannot be measured exactly, but only up to some threshold. As we shall explain in the Conclusion, this finite-valuedness assumption does not decrease the computational power of our fuzzy P-systems: if we allowed the reactives to take values in the whole [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], the set of natural numbers generated by a fuzzy P-system would still be finite-valued.

We shall say that an object x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in Xitalic_x ∈ italic_X is similar to a reactive v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in Vitalic_v ∈ italic_V when v⁢(x)>0𝑣𝑥0v(x)>0italic_v ( italic_x ) > 0. To simplify the definition of an application of a rule, and as it was already hinted in §2.1, we shall assume in this paper that each object in X𝑋Xitalic_X is similar to at most one reactive, and it will be clear from the definition of the application of a rule that in each fuzzy P-system we shall not care about objects that are not similar to some reactive among those used in it.

As in the crisp case, fuzzy P-systems will be supported by a membrane structure and each membrane in it will define a region. But, the reactives being fuzzy sets, the content of these regions at each moment will be formally described by means of an M¯¯𝑀\overline{M}over¯ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG-indexed family of fuzzy multisets over a set V𝑉Vitalic_V of reactives. These fuzzy multisets specify, for every v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in Vitalic_v ∈ italic_V and for every value t∈]0,1]t\in]0,1]italic_t ∈ ] 0 , 1 ], how many objects in each region Kmsubscript𝐾𝑚K_{m}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are copies of the reactive v𝑣vitalic_v with degree of accuracy t𝑡titalic_t.

Since each fuzzy P-system will involve only a finite set of reactives V𝑉Vitalic_V, and, for the purposes of each specific P-system, we consider each reactive as a finite-valued fuzzy subset of X𝑋Xitalic_X, all possible values of accuracy of objects to reactives used in a given fuzzy P-system form a finite subset of [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ]. Thus, we shall specify in the description of a fuzzy P-system a finite subset I𝐼Iitalic_I of [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ] that will contain all these images as well as all other elements in [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ] needed in that description. Then, a configuration for this fuzzy P-system, with set of membranes M𝑀Mitalic_M and set of reactives V𝑉Vitalic_V, will be a family of I𝐼Iitalic_I-valued fuzzy multisets (Fm)m∈M¯subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑚𝑚¯𝑀(F_{m})_{m\in\overline{M}}( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over V𝑉Vitalic_V,

Let us point out again that a given rule may admit several applications to a given configuration, yielding different results, depending on the mappings taken in steps (1) and (2). This does not happen in the crisp case.

Now, a transition for a fuzzy P-system ΠΠ\Piroman_Π consists of a maximal simultaneous application of rules in the same sense as in the crisp case: the triggering condition must be satisfied simultaneously for all rules, and then all steps (1) and (2) corresponding to rules being applied in one transition are performed simultaneously, and finally all steps (3) are performed together. The rules applied in a given transition are chosen non-deterministically but so that no further rule in ℛmsubscriptℛ𝑚\mathcal{R}_{m}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any m𝑚mitalic_m can be triggered simultaneously to them. In particular, a given rule can be triggered several times in the same transition, provided enough copies of the corresponding incoming and outgoing reactives are available within the required degree of exactitude.

A finite sequence of transitions between configurations of a fuzzy P-system ΠΠ\Piroman_Π, starting with the initial configuration, is called a computation with respect to ΠΠ\Piroman_Π. A computation halts when it reaches a halting configuration where no rule can be triggered.

4 Universality

A fuzzy language over an alphabet ΣΣ\Sigmaroman_Σ is a fuzzy subset L:Σ*→[0,1]:𝐿→superscriptΣ01L:\Sigma^{*}\to[0,1]italic_L : roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → [ 0 , 1 ] of Σ*superscriptΣ\Sigma^{*}roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Such a fuzzy language is recursively enumerable when all its levels

Lt={w∈Σ*∣L⁢(w)≥t},t∈[0,1],formulae-sequencesubscript𝐿𝑡conditional-set𝑤superscriptΣ𝐿𝑤𝑡𝑡01L_{t}=\{w\in\Sigma^{*}\mid L(w)\geq t\},\quad t\in[0,1],italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_w ∈ roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_L ( italic_w ) ≥ italic_t } , italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] ,

are recursively enumerable in the usual sense; cf. [fre]. Notice that, since L0=Σ*subscript𝐿0superscriptΣL_{0}=\Sigma^{*}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, it is enough to consider in this definition the t𝑡titalic_t-levels with t>0𝑡0t>0italic_t > 0. Moreover, arguing as at the beginning of §2.1, we can see that if L𝐿Litalic_L is I𝐼Iitalic_I-valued, then it is enough to consider its t𝑡titalic_t-levels with t∈I+𝑡superscript𝐼t\in I^{+}italic_t ∈ italic_I start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Now, in parallel to the definition of a recursively enumerable subset of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N as the set of lengths of some recursively enumerable language, we shall say that a fuzzy subset F:ℕ→[0,1]:𝐹→ℕ01F:\mathbb{N}\to[0,1]italic_F : blackboard_N → [ 0 , 1 ] of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N is recursively enumerable when there exists some recursively enumerable fuzzy language L:Σ*→[0,1]:𝐿→superscriptΣ01L:\Sigma^{*}\to[0,1]italic_L : roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → [ 0 , 1 ], over some alphabet ΣΣ\Sigmaroman_Σ, such that, for every n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}italic_n ∈ blackboard_N,

F⁢(n)=⋁{L⁢(w)∣w∈Σ*,|w|=n}.𝐹𝑛conditional-set𝐿𝑤formulae-sequence𝑤superscriptΣ𝑤𝑛F(n)=\bigvee\{L(w)\mid w\in\Sigma^{*},\ |w|=n\}.italic_F ( italic_n ) = ⋁ { italic_L ( italic_w ) ∣ italic_w ∈ roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , | italic_w | = italic_n } .

Now we have the following characterization of recursively enumerable fuzzy subsets of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N in terms of levels, which is the one we shall use henceforth.

Proposition 2

An I𝐼Iitalic_I-valued fuzzy subset F:ℕ→Inormal-:𝐹normal-→ℕ𝐼F:\mathbb{N}\to Iitalic_F : blackboard_N → italic_I is recursively enumerable if and only if Ftsubscript𝐹𝑡F_{t}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a recursively enumerable subset of ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N, for every t∈I+𝑡superscript𝐼t\in I^{+}italic_t ∈ italic_I start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.
